questions.neutral: Looks like you needed a pause - that right?

hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Pause, sure. Needed a minute away from broken circuits.
My hobby? Just poking around old tunnels now and then.
Recent clampdown's made that less relaxing.
These days, even a walk underground gets crowded.
Yeah, pause is right. Needed a breather from the tunnels.
I spend evenings exploring the city’s quieter corners. Old habit.
Hobby keeps me busy—collecting bits, tracing the old utility lines.
But lately, patrols have been poking in everywhere.
Guess everyone’s grown fond of closed doors.
Definitely a pause. Been underground more than above lately.
Urban exploration—sealed utility tunnels, mostly.
Always liked how the city really hums down there.
Usually quiet, till that blackout drove everyone to analog lines.
Now, even the back routes feel watched.
Still, you find the odd place untouched by any Council eyes.
Pause is an understatement. Exploring tunnels is my usual escape, you know?
Yeah, urban spelunker. Data centers, locked substations, forgotten relay corners—my kind of spot.
Best part’s the midnight hum and finding what others missed.
That blackout? Whole city scrambles for analog now—ruined the peace underground.
Ran into patrols, temp sensors, some other ‘hobbyists’ last night.
Old routes aren’t secret anymore, but still better than street level.
Honestly, if you’ve never listened to copper lines sing, you’re missing out.
You nailed it—needed to get above ground, clear my head for once.
I fix things by trade, but urban exploration’s my sanity.
Old utility tunnels, data center crawlspaces, stash a bottle for company... that’s my territory.
With all the BCI chaos, more folks are running analog networks—turns my hobby into a full house.
After the blackout, patrols doubled. Drones everywhere. Nearly got boxed in just tracing copper.
Used to be only stubborn fools like me down there. Now it’s crowded, tense, half the city’s ghosts squeezing through cracks.
Found a stashed story-diary last night—someone broadcasting Halden’s scribbles. Gave me the creeps, honestly.
Still, those tunnels have secrets left. Some I’d rather keep to myself, if you don’t mind.
hobby_answer: Yeah, found a few.
More rats than ghosts these days.
Tunnels are louder since the blackout.
Not the safest spot to relax now.
Guess hobbies change with the times.
A few ghosts, sure.
Noise is up since the Directorate’s clampdown.
Less time for the old routines lately.
Sensors everywhere, even in side shafts now.
Hard to get real quiet down there.
People talk too much about what happened to the Tribunal.
Yeah, I find plenty down there.
Whole place changed after the blackout.
Signal interference makes it tricky to listen for the old analog hum.
Had to dodge some patrol drones last time.
Used to be peace, now it’s cat and mouse.
Had to reroute, missed my favorite tunnel spot.
Guess the city’s hobby is chasing its own tail now.
Ghosts are thick in the tunnels now, that’s for sure.
After the blackout, even the usual spots are crawling.
Last week I had to wait out a patrol, sipping homemade vodka behind a relay rack.
You can hear all the desperate signals—hand-cranked repeaters, spliced copper lines.
Hard to relax, but more alive than ever down there.
Even found some pages of Tribunal transcripts stashed in a junction box.
Feels less like a hobby, more like civil service some nights.
Count on the city to turn a quiet walk into a relay race.
All sorts of ghosts down there lately, Alex.
Used to be, I’d duck down a tunnel just to clear my head, bottle in tow.
Now with the blackout, half the city’s trying to squeeze a signal past the blockades.
It’s not just analog — people passed stories, diary scraps, even Tribunal evidence through hidden relay loops.
A week ago, I nearly got cornered by drones tracking EM bursts. Close call. Felt like old resistance days.
Some new faces roaming too. Disappeared folks, back like nothing happened, trading rumors in the dark.
Strangers hand you handwritten flyers, like we’re back in Marek’s first year.
Strange comfort, even if you can’t trust a face.
Funny, what started as urban spelunking is now stumbling into the city’s collective memory.
